review.title: Incorporating Causal Prior Knowledge as Path-Constraints in Bayesian Networks and Maximal Ancestral Graphs
review.abstract: We consider the incorporation of causal knowledge about the presence or absence of (possibly indirect) causal relations into a causal model. Such causal relations correspond to directed paths in a causal model. This type of knowledge naturally arises from experimental data, among others. Specifically, we consider the formalisms of Causal Bayesian Networks and Maximal Ancestral Graphs and their Markov equivalence classes: Partially Directed Acyclic Graphs and Partially Oriented Ancestral Graphs. We introduce sound and complete procedures which are able to incorporate causal prior knowledge in such models. In simulated experiments, we show that often considering even a few causal facts leads to a significant number of new inferences. In a case study, we also show how to use real experimental data to infer causal knowledge and incorporate it into a real biological causal network. The code is available at mensxmachina.org.

sections.heading: 7. Conclusion
sections.text: We present algorithms for including path constraints in PDAGs and PAGs that correspond to known, possibly indirect causal correlations, using a chronological traceability search with forward verification and a circumcision rule derived from the semantics of graphs, as well as an industry and cross-border variation in algorithms for handling knowledge that is not consistent with the given PDAG or PAG. Our experimental results show that typically, even some causal constraints can orient a significant number of edges. In a case study, we show how experimental studies (where some variables are manipulated) can be used to derive such causal constraints and incorporate them into an incomplete (i.e., structural) causal model. The algorithms could provide a basis for extensions that take into account the degree of belief in any limitation or network function.
